We believe Japanese stocks' August rally was driven by the view that the yen will appreciate only moderately from a supply/demand perspective, even amid rising expectations for Fed rate cuts and a BOJ rate hike. Apr- Jun earnings were weak due to US tariff impact. However, based on companies' views of the tariff impacts and their countermeasures, we expect both company and market forecasts to be raised. If tariff impact becomes manageable, the likelihood of a BOJ rate hike would increase. May- July data showed corporate reform progress in FY2024, but this was not priced in owing to high uncertainty over tariffs. With the final tariff agreement, we think corporate reform is starting to be priced into stocks. Inflows continued in August, driven by futures buying. Cash equity

Kouzumi or Mr. Takayuki Hayashi became prime minister. If Ms. Sanae Takaichi takes over, dovish policies are likely, but some see the likelihood of this scenario declining with the rebound in cabinet approval
Our sector analysts expect that in the automotive sector, tariff impact can

be managed given cuts in environmental regulation costs, leading to a change in sector stance from bearish to bullish. In industrial electronics, strong demand for digital transformation (DX) and the need for power transmission and distribution installations continue to support a bullish outlook. In pharmaceuticals, the retreat from a cautious stance due to policy risks is expected to lead to a stock price recovery.

We expect auto sector positioning to shift from overweight to neutral owing to cost pass- throughs. However, our strategy remains centered on domestic demand- driven sectors (IT services, defense, Internet, financials, and real estate) as core holdings given our expectation for gradual yen appreciation in September onward based on Fed and BOJ policies. We look for investment opportunities in consumer- related sectors as inflation eases and in the capital goods sector given corporate investment.

10. The TSE reforms are broadening to SMEs. The number of TOPIX constituents is to be reduced from about 1,700 in 2025 to about 1,200 in 2028.

We expect sustained reforms led by companies and the market to drive balance sheet efficiency and increase the total returns ratio from the recent \(60\%\) in FY2024 to \(70\%\) in five years. With these factors, together with growth investments and market reform effects (the removal of low- ROE companies from TOPIX), we expect corporate ROE to rise from \(9.4\%\) in FY2024 to \(10\%\) in FY2026 and \(11\%\) in FY2028, even in the yen appreciation phase that should occur. In other words, ROE, which remained around the \(9\%\) range during FY2022- 24, seems to have entered an upward cycle due to the acceleration of corporate reforms starting from FY2024 (Key Chart).

Part of the reason for the market rally may be a pricing in of growth in fiscal spending following the ruling party's major losses in the July upper house elections. Furthermore, if the new administration becomes a majority government, it would be positive due to the resulting political stability.

Some think that the left wing, which wants to prevent opposition parties from challenging the Ishiba administration and thwart a potential Takaichi administration, is involved in the high approval ratings, and that Prime Minister Ishiba could still step down.

However, the rebound in the cabinet approval ratings suggests a rising likelihood that an increase in fiscal spending will be milder than what was expected when votes were counted for the upper house elections.

On September 2, the LDP's election committee will summarize the upper house election results, and Secretary- General Hiroshi Moriyama will indicate his intention on a course of action. If the LDP presidential election is moved up owing to the recall provision (a majority vote of Diet members and the 47 prefectures), a change of administration could happen in late September or early October. Even if the recall provision does not immediately trigger a presidential election, there will continue to be fundamental problems associated with a minority ruling party coalition, which could eventually result in a presidential election.

Regardless of who becomes prime minister, if the new administration has at least a majority in the lower house, it would be positive from the standpoint of political stability. Economic policy would likely not change much from the current one if Mr. Koizumi or Mr. Hayashi becomes prime minister. If Ms. Takaichi takes over, dovish policies are likely, but some see the likelihood of this scenario declining with the rebound in the cabinet's approval ratings, and market volatility triggered by a leadership election could be averted. The likelihood of agricultural and labor market reforms as well as pro- business reforms in the case of a new Koizumi administration would be positive for the market.

Apr- Jun results weakApr- Jun earnings were weak owing to US tariff impact (25% on autos). Guidance at the beginning of the fiscal year is often conservative (calling for earnings to decline forecast). FY2025 guidance started with a 6% earnings decline (earnings wrap- up report). TOPIX companies' Apr- Jun net profit fell 17% YoY but was roughly flat excluding one- time factors related to tariffs and electric power.

We expect both company and market forecasts to be revised upward. After the 15% tariff was finalized, 42 major companies (Nikkei 225 companies that disclosed tariff impact) estimated a total impact of about 4 trillion on FY2025 operating profit (source: Nikkei survey, Japanese only). Of this, the auto sector accounted for 80% (Figure 13).

Meanwhile, based on our estimates since April, the impact of tariffs on EPS growth is - 6ppts YoY, which works out to about 5- 6 trillion in operating profit for TOPIX companies. By late July, the market had generally priced this impact into EPS forecasts (Figure 10). The market seems to have already factored in a greater tariff impact than companies expect. With tariff impact to be reflected in earnings going forward, market EPS forecasts now look likely to be revised upward.

Although the actual impact of tariffs will emerge later, market forecasts have sufficiently priced in tariff impact while corporate guidance may not fully factor in the effects of countermeasures. The TOPIX EPS consensus estimate turned upward in the week of August 22 (Figure 11).

Companies have also mentioned countermeasures. Daikin and Shin- Etsu Chemical intend to offset tariff impact by passing on related costs, while Fujifilm announced it will respond by assessing/changing its production sites and cutting costs (source: August 15 Nikkei, Japanese only). We believe the tariff impact indicated by the companies this earnings season generally reflects the finalization of the tariff rate at 15% but does not reflect the impact of countermeasures.

Possible catalystsPossible catalysts include upward revisions to market forecasts and/or corporate guidance (when 1H results come out) or reversals of monthly export prices, volumes, and amounts. July trade statistics showed the value of exports fell 2.6% YoY, export prices declined 3.7%, and export volume rose 1.2% (Figure 14). With progress on countermeasures, guidance could be revised upward.

Global equity fund flow data from EPFR show that overseas investors temporarily withdrew funds from Japan's market after the US jobs report in early August but then continued to put funds into Japanese stocks on rising expectations for a prompt Fed rate cut and yen appreciation (Figure 16). TSE fund flow data (for the weeks of August 1- 22) show inflows from overseas investors continued in August, with cumulative net buying on a cash and futures basis of about ¥1.8 trillion (Figure 17). While cash buying slowed owing to the weak jobs report, futures buying exceeded ¥1 trillion and momentum picked up. Since "Liberation Day" in April 2025, overseas investors have been net buyers by about ¥9 trillion cumulatively (Figure 18). Among other investor groups, individuals and trust banks were major net sellers, while share buybacks by nonfinancial companies remained firm.

The August QUICK survey (response period: August 5- 7) shows that investor intentions at the beginning of the month were to reduce underweight positions on autos, among the overseas demand- driven sectors, while increasing overweight positions on steel, machinery, electrical machinery/precision instruments, and financials, which are also regarded as heavily affected by tariffs. While the overweight positions on domestic demand were generally maintained, positions on pharmaceuticals, food, and utilities remained underweight (Figure 20 and Figure 21).

In July, we raised our end- 2025 price targets for Japan's market (TOPIX 3,000, Nikkei 225 42,000; Figure 22 and Figure 23) in response to the reduction in auto tariffs as a result of the US- Japan tariff agreement and the diminished uncertainty. We estimated 12- month forward EPS growth of \(7\%\) YoY at end- 2025 and an end- 2025 P/E of 14.5x. Subsequently, after the release of the US jobs report August 1, expectations for a preemptive rate cut increased, supporting stock prices. Limited expectations for yen appreciation, even if the Fed cuts rates, and the improvement in Japan's GDP, QMI, and economic surprise index supported Japanese stocks (Figure 28). With companies' AprJun earnings results, it became clear that the market had sufficiently priced in US tariff impact, and corporate reform also became more appreciated, leading Japan's market to outperform other developed markets (Figure 24).

Near- term catalysts include the risk of a US economic slowdown, the pace of Fed rate cuts, the timing of a BOJ rate hike, and Japanese political developments, such as a change of administration. If a new administration takes over and a majority can be secured in the lower house elections, Japan's political situation will stabilize, and the policy focus is likely to shift to growth strategies. Fiscal expansion, which is likely in the fall, would provide some support for the economy.

Medium- term catalysts include whether there are upward revisions to corporate guidance and/or analysts' estimates around the time of the 1H results announcements or later. In particular, we see potential for upward guidance revisions as the impact of countermeasures announced by companies, such as cost pass- throughs, reviews of/ changes to production sites, and cost reductions, has not yet been factored in yet. Long- term catalysts include a rise in ROE toward \(10\%\) , with progress on such corporate reforms as increased shareholder payouts and corporate investment, and a consequent revaluation of Japanese stocks.

Expect tariff impact to be digested, upward earnings estimate revisions from fall With the reduced tariff that the US and Japan agreed to on July 23, the focus will be on how tariff impact on corporate earnings is priced in. Based on the already completed Apr- Jun results announcements, we estimate tariff impact on the six major automakers totaled \(780 billion, with impact on operating profit of TSE Prime- listed companies at 4\%. Once the reduced auto tariff takes effect, we think the impact on operating profit of Japanese companies in FY2025 could be limited to about 2\%. In fact, the forecasts of 42 major companies (Nikkei 225 companies that disclosed the amount of tariff impact) show a total impact of about \(4 trillion on FY2025 operating profit (source: Nikkei survey, Japanese only), more limited than our estimate. In addition, the effect of the countermeasures against tariff impact disclosed by companies has probably not been reflected yet in guidance, so upward revisions are likely during the earnings results season in the fall onward.

The current IBES estimate for FY2025 TOPIX EPS growth is \(0.9\%\) YoY, down 9ppts year to date and reflecting greater tariff impact than what companies have disclosed (Figure 35; as of August 22). Given that earnings impact has been mitigated by the reduced tariff and that the impact of the strong yen on earnings remains limited (based on the forward curve as of August 26, we estimate that the strong yen will depress FY2025 TOPIX EPS by \(1\%\) ), our TOPIX EPS estimate is \(198 (+5.4\%\) YoY) for FY2025 and \(214 (+8.0\%\) YoY) for FY2026. Our 12- month forward estimate at end- 2025 is \(210 (+7.4\%\) YoY), slightly above consensus.

Japanese stocks have risen substantially since early August, and TOPIX's 12- month forward P/E (IBES basis) as of August 27 was 15.3x, above the median since 2012 (Figure 40). However, for the short term, stocks do not look overvalued in light of the likelihood of upward earnings estimate revisions. With the Apr- Jun results announcements complete and analysts proceeding with their estimate reviews, the TOPIX EPS revision index returned to positive territory in the week of August 22 (Figure 11). We think this earnings improvement momentum will support Japanese stock valuations in the short term (P/E on our 12- month forward EPS estimate is about 15x). Furthermore, in the longer term, as progress is made on corporate reforms, we think the Japanese market's P/E could reach 17- 18x, the level during the Koizumi era.

Since April 2, overseas demand- driven sectors and banks have significantly underperformed TOPIX. Japanese stocks subsequently rebounded on rising expectations for Fed rate cuts and the US- Japan agreement, erasing most of their decline owing to the reciprocal tariff announcement. The rebound in stocks during this period was led by overseas demand theme groups, such as heavy industry in the machinery sector and semiconductor- related stocks in the electrical machinery/precision sector, as well as information & communication/services (including games), construction/materials, trading companies, banks, and insurance. Among major theme groups, US policy beneficiary stocks, stocks with a high likelihood of trimming strategic shareholdings, high- quality/value stocks, DX- related stocks, and reshoring stocks did well.

While we maintain our fundamental- based overweight stance on domestic demand- driven sectors for the medium term, we assume that if a new administration takes over in Japan in the next few weeks to a month, cyclical overseas demand- driven sectors will outperform, and tactically, we would overweight overseas demand- driven stocks. Among domestic demand- driven sectors, we maintain our overweight stance on IT services, information & communication, real estate, and defense, where domestic demand is likely to be stable; food and transportation, where margin and ROE improvement and increases in shareholder returns are likely; and retail, which should benefit from a recovery in consumer spending and ongoing inbound tourism. Within the financial sector, we maintain our overweight stance on banks. For the time being, we maintain a neutral stance on the insurance sector, where rising long- term interest rates are likely to be a focus and a deterioration in securities valuation gains/losses is a concern.
Our sector preferences are shown in Figure 44 and major stocks in each sector in Figure 45.

Our style preferences are shown in Figure 47. In Japan, long- term yields fluctuated around the time of the upper house elections owing to concerns about the expanding fiscal deficit, but we think the BOJ will continue to raise its policy rate moderately. For the rest of the year, we think value and dividend stocks will continue to outperform the overall market because the weighting of companies with a low P/B (below 1x) is still around \(40\%\) , and there are expectations for continued corporate governance reform. However, while small caps may be bought on low valuations in the short term, we maintain our underweight stance on them because they are more vulnerable to domestic rate increases than large caps are, and their progress on corporate reform has been relatively slow.

The sector outlooks of our analysts are summarized in Figure 50 and Figure 51.

Among overseas demand- related sectors, for the auto sector (Akira Kishimoto), the reduction of the US- Japan auto tariff to \(15\%\) should bring the impact of tariffs to a manageable range, mainly for major companies, and regulatory compliance costs in the US are very likely to be reduced owing to the easing of environmental regulations. Our sector stance is thus bullish. For the electronics/precision sector (Junya Ayada), we see ongoing structural demand tailwinds for industrial electronics as demand related to modernization and DX remains strong, mainly in Japan, and power demand from data centers associated with upgrades of power facilities and the proliferation of AI continues to boost demand for power transmission/distribution/installation. For semiconductors (Mio Shikanai), the situation remains difficult to be optimistic about, especially for the front- end processes, given the uncertainty over semiconductor tariffs and a slowdown in legacy demand in China. For electronic components (Akinori Kanemoto), a recovery in orders and sales of components for autos and industrial machinery, where inventories continue to be reduced, is gradually becoming clear, but momentum for automotive components remains weak, so our sector stance remains neutral. For pharmaceuticals (Seiji Wakao), we think sector stocks will start to recover as cautious views on US policy risk ease as the Apr- Jun results were good.

Among domestic demand- related sectors, for retail (Dairo Murata), unexpected cost increase factors were limited in the latest quarterly results amid firm demand and price pass- throughs. For cosmetics/toiletries (Akiko Kuwahara), cosmetics are showing signs of bottoming out in the Chinese market, but in Japan, uncertainty is increasing owing to a slowdown in inbound demand. For toiletries, we expect progress on adding high value and raising prices in Japan. For food (Satoshi Fujiwara), the negative aspects of a demand decline owing to prolonged food inflation are notable, but we also like companies that can be expected to increase ROE by boosting shareholder returns using financial leverage. For IT services (Matthew Henderson), overseas market conditions continue to be challenging owing to corporate investment cutbacks and project delays, but we think the momentum of IT investment by domestic companies is strong. For games (Junko Yamamura), the focus is on multi- platformization, the game industry as an IP business, and sales growth in emerging countries. We think the trend of mobile games emerging as a new IP business platform will accelerate.

Within the financial sector, for banks (Takahiro Yano), the latest results show that domestic net interest income continued to increase, and the business environment continues to be particularly favorable for banks heavily dependent on domestic interest rate- based businesses. For insurance/other financials (Koki Sato), uncertainties such as the impact of tariffs have hardly materialized, and even after 1Q results announcements, there have been no factors that would significantly change the outlook for the companies' fundamentals.
Figure 50:Sector analyst outlooks following April-June earnings: Overseas demand

SectorCommentAutos, Auto PartsOur auto sector stance is bullish. Our order of preference within subsectors is assemblers first, followed by tires, and then auto parts. With the reduction of Japanese and US automobile tariffs to 15%, the impact of tariffs, particularly on major companies, should be manageable. However, a range of environmental regulations such as GHG, CAFE, and ACC-II have been eased, and we think the cost of regulatory compliance in the US is likely to be significantly reduced from FY2026. We think the upside from deregulation could outweigh the downside of tariffs for assemblers, particularly for Toyota. With a high likelihood of a recovery in HEV and ICE demand, we also expect a scenario for growth in market share of Japanese assemblers. We also expect further growth in automatic and continuously variable transmissions, which are a cash cow for Aisin (Akira Kishimoto)Consumer/ Industrial Electronics/ PrecisionIn industrial electronics, structural demand tailwinds continue. For IT investments, modernization and DX demand remain strong, particularly in Japan. Additionally, major IT service companies are transitioning from custom-based Sler-type business models to standardized offering models, which address management issues unique to each client, and we expect this transition to keep contributing to margin improvements. For infrastructure investment, power equipment installation needs are being boosted by the replacement of power facilities and strong data center electricity demand, supported by the penetration of AI. Although capex lacks strength, it is in a gradual recovery phase. Based on these considerations, we focus on NEC (6701, OW) and Fujitsu (6702, OW) in the industrial electronics sector. In contrast, there are concerns about a demand slowdown for consumer electronics and precision instruments due to inflation. With limited room for hardware innovation, consumer budgets are likely to continue shifting towards services and entertainment content. We are focusing on Sony Group (6758, OW) in the consumer electronics sector. (Junya Ayada)Semiconductor/ Technical materials/Cement(1) Semiconductors: Due to the uncertainty surrounding semiconductor tariff trends and the slowdown in legacy demand from China, the situation remains challenging, particularly for the front-end. We continue to watch Adanest (6857, OW), where we have high expectations for EPS growth. (2) Glass: European architectural glass is showing signs of market improvement due to supply restrictions. Additionally, semiconductor-related glass remains steady. We expect Nippon Electric Glass (5214, OW) to have various opportunities in semiconductor support glass. (3) Cement: While domestic cement price revisions are progressing steadily, demand remains challenging. (Mio Shikani)Electronic ComponentsWe maintain our neutral sector stance. Orders and sales are gradually starting to show signs of recovery in automotive and industrial machinery applications, which are currently in a phase of inventory adjustment, but momentum remains weak in the automotive field. In the short term, we focus on Nidec, where the stock price is lagging. Against this backdrop, we will watch the trend in MLCC utilization rates into 2H 2025. Capacity utilization rates at MLCC manufacturers have risen to close to 90%, but we will watch trends in the latter half of 2025 to determine whether there will be a gradual recovery, largely determined by movements in final demand, and whether that recovery ends up being short-lived, as in the 2024 cycle, or whether there is a full-scale recovery that leads to tighter supply/demand conditions heading into 2026. (Akinori Kanemoto)ChemicalsIn the petrochemical and commodity materials areas, there were companies experiencing steady performance despite the global supply-demand imbalance. This was due to the positive effects of transforming their business portfolios and the strong performance of specialty products. In the petrochemical sector, many companies anticipate an improvement in the operating rates of naphtha crackers from July to September onwards. However, this outlook may seem optimistic due to the decrease in regular maintenance. We look for earnings improvement driven by strong demand for advanced semiconductor materials, the reduction of unprofitable businesses, and the effects of M&A. (Yasuhiro Nakada)SteelWe have a mixed impression of steel fundamentals. At 1Q earnings, Nippon Steel and JFE cut full-year guidance on an adjusted basis excluding revisions of FX assumptions and tariff impact. In particular, this was due to deterioration in export profitability from foreign trade measures and continued weakness in steel prices. Domestic demand also remained weak from both the construction and manufacturing sectors. However, since July, there has been a rebound and stabilization in the Asian market due to expectations for China's anti-involvement policies (aimed at reducing excess competition), production cuts due to environmental regulations, and price increases by major steel companies. We expect production cuts in China to continue, reflecting the anti-involvement campaign, and if price increases by steel companies in take hold, market conditions could improve towards autumn even if only gradually. We focus on JFE (5411, OW), which has high exposure to the Asian market. (Tatsuya Maruyama)PharmaceuticalsWith cautious views on US policy risk easing and favorable earnings confirmed in April-June results, we believe the pharmaceutical sector is entering a phase of stock price recovery. September is the academic conference season, and we expect updates from companies to further improve sector sentiment. Until now, the shares of mid-sized companies with limited impact from US policy have performed well, but from here on, we expect large companies to take the lead. We recommend Otsuka Holdings, which has strong current performance and where we feel negatives have been exhausted, and Chugai Pharmaceutical, which saw a significant drop in stock price following the off-rigorization results that fell short of expectations. (Seiji Wakao)MedTech &amp; ServiceIn the medical equipment sector, the share prices of Asahi Intec, Terumo, Nipro, and disposable product manufacturers rose after April-June results announcements, and we think these gains exhausted share-price advances for the near term. Share prices of Sysmex, Olympus, and other capital product manufacturers, meanwhile, declined after results. We think the valuations of these companies are near a bottom amid impact from deterioration in Chinese market conditions, though the timing of a recovery is unclear. While Shimadzu trades at a low valuation and is affected by the worsening Chinese market, we expect its shares to rise moderately on the prospect of recovery from Jul-Sep because it caters to a wide range of industries. In the healthcare services sector, we anticipate continued recovery from weakness in FY2024 by M3 and JMDC. (Naoko Saito)

SectorCommentRetailingOperating profit growth is in line with or above guidance at more than 80% of our coverage companies, and earnings are generally favorable. We see few factors that could unexpectedly drive up costs amid strong demand and successful price pass-through. However, share prices at most companies are favorable and within or above a fair-value range, making it more challenging to choose where to shift. Among lagging large-cap stocks, we focus on Fast Retailing, which we rate Overweight (Dairo Murata)TransportationIn an overall strong market supported by receding tariff concerns, expectations of lower US interest rates, and solid stock supply and demand, railway and logistics sector stocks outperformed TOPIX, particularly in summer. Railway shares seem to have been slow to reflect their value, real estate shares were reassessed, and logistics shares were also slow to reflect their value, while improving volumes and rising unit prices also contributed. We still see risk of share price corrections when tariffs are finalized, but would still be bullish on domestic logistics operations for their improving fundamentals and relatively limited tariff impact. The external environment will be a major factor, but if Bank of Japan interest rate hikes establish a trend for rising rates and a strengthening yen, we would expect transportation to be preferred over railways. Also, if higher interest rates put value stocks in focus, shipping sector plays could also become a preference. (Ryota Himeno)Cosmetics &amp; Personal careWhile there are signs of a bottoming out in the cosmetics market in China, uncertainty about the future is increasing in Japan due to factors such as a slowdown in inbound demand. In the personal care sector, there is progress in adding value and raising prices domestically in Japan. Although the personal care goods market in Asia is highly volatile, companies are accelerating their responses. We focus on Lion, which in addition to the benefits of domestic price increases in personal care goods, has begun to see its high-value-added strategy take effect. (Akiko Kuwahara)Paper &amp; PackagingDomestically, Oji Holdings has announced price increases for container board and corrugated products, as well as printing and information paper. Price pass-through momentum is growing. Overseas, the market recovery for both pulp and corrugated products is delayed. We focus on Oji Holdings due to its efforts in improving profit margins and advancing balance sheet reforms. (Akiko Kuwahara)Internet, Media, GameOur core recommendations in the game industry are Nintendo, Bandai Namco HD, and Konami. In the internet and services sector, we recommend OLC. In the games industry, we are focusing on 1) multiplatformization, 2) the game industry as an IP business, and 3) the expansion of sales in emerging markets. In the latest earnings, mobile games further emerged as a new platform for IP business, along with improved profitability through off-app purchases. We believe this trend will continue to accelerate. (Junko Yamamura)IT servicesApril-June results for domestic system integrators (Siers) show continued strong IT demand, with particularly strong IT investment momentum in the financial sector. Domestically, we see no short-term risk factors, but the overseas market continues to face a challenging environment due to companies limiting investment and delaying projects. The Japanese IT services sector is the only one maintaining high valuations. Meanwhile, in the telecommunications sector, among NTT, KDDI, and SoftBank, only SoftBank reported favorable results, and we expect this situation to continue for some time. (Matthew Henderson)FoodDeclining demand due to prolonged food inflation has become notable. We think the companies that can overcome this and achieve high growth are limited to Ajinomoto (with non-food businesses such as ABF and CDMO as drivers) and Kewpie (with overseas business as a driver). However, we would also watch companies that we expect to increase ROE by utilizing financial leverage and enhancing shareholder returns. Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan Holdings and Asahi Group Holdings fall into this category. (Satoshi Fujiwara)BanksIn 1Q FY2025, the YoY change in net profit was around 0% for the megabanks and about +10% or higher for Japan Post Bank and regional banks. Domestic net interest income (NII) continued to grow, so we view the current business environment as particularly positive for banks which depend more on domestic interest rate business. Against this backdrop, assuming a BoJ rate hike is around the corner, we particularly recommend Japan Post Bank, where ROE improvement was slower than peers until FY2024. (Takahiro Yano)Insurance, Diversified FinancialsWe believe that there were no major changes in the fundamental outlook following 1Q earnings, as uncertainties such as tariff impact have not significantly materialized. In the short term (the next three months), P&amp;C insurers and ORIX (8591, N) may attract attention, as we see a possibility they will raise full-year guidance at 2Q results. Additionally, we expect Dai-ichi Life Holdings (8750), which had a low progress rate in 1Q, to catch up from 2Q onwards due to higher-than-expected gains from stock sales, supported by Japan's robust stock market. (Koki Sato)
